newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel surprised at reported Orbit cancellation.
newsitem.headline: Israel surprised at reported Orbit cancellation.

text.p: Israel's Ministry of Industry and Trade said on Tuesday it was surprised by local media reports that California-based Orbit Semiconductor Inc had cancelled plans to build a plant in Eilat.
David Baruch, director of the ministry's Investment Centre, said he had received no announcement of the cancellation but had read of it in local newspapers on Tuesday.

"We gave them a chance to continue the dialogue regarding the investment even after it appeared it was not a worthwhile project from Israel's point of view. But in the meantime they (apparently) have decided to pull the project," Baruch said.

Israeli dailies reported on Tuesday that Orbit, a wholly owned subsidiary of the DII Group Inc, was cancelling plans to invest $230 million in a proposed semiconductor plant in Israel's southern port of Eilat.
The media said Orbit blamed bureaucratic red tape for the decision. Orbit officials were not available to comment.
Baruch dismissed the charge of excessive redtape.
Orbit approached the Investment Centre in January 1996, seeking the centre's approved enterprise designation which would have made it eligible to obtain a 30 percent government grant.
Last month Vishay Intertechnology cancelled plans for a $50 million plant in the development town of Ofakim following what it called bureaucratic delays in getting a government subsidy.
